questions.question: Where are you in your educational journey?

answers.answer: I'm currently in school for a health care related degree
I'm considering going back to school for a health care related degree
I'm considering going back to school for a degree that isn't related to health care
I'm not currently considering going back to school

questions.question: At work, a primary motivator for me is...

answers.answer: Helping others do their best at work. I like to develop plans and communicate them to a team.
Improving a person's quality of life and health. I like to help people.
Lifelong learning. I like to teach others and give them the tools to help themselves.
Making groundbreaking discoveries. I like to figure out how things work.
Finding insights in data. I like to develop and maintain systems and solve problems.
Health care providers and am interested in managing staff or finances.
Patients and other medical professionals.
Community residents, aspiring health care professionals, or people with disabilities.
Other scientists or medical professionals.
Medical professionals and computer systems.
In a hospital or physician's office, but I'd be open to a residential care facility or government agency.
In a physician's office, hospital, or outpatient care center.
At a government agency or nonprofit, but I'd be open to working at a university or family services organization.
In a lab or at a university, but I'd be open to working in a hospital or office.
In an office or hospital, but I'd be open to working in a technical services or administrative support organization.
Leading and communicating with others. I have good attention to detail and enjoy analyzing information and using technology.
Empathetic communication and emotional stablility. I have strong problem-solving and interpersonal skills.
Breaking down big ideas so others can learn. I'm also good at analyzing information to inform big-picture problem solving.
Critical thinking, observation, and data analysis. I can also communicate complex ideas simply while speaking and writing.
Organization, project management, data analysis, and creative problem solving.

questions.question: I have taken college courses in ...

answers.answer: Accounting, administration, ethics, or economics.
Physical sciences or health care.
Education, public health, ethics, or a language.
Physical science such as biology or chemistry.
Biology, computer science, math, or management.
Some experience in an administrative or clinical role.
Some experience working in a lab setting or with patients as a medic, nurse, medical assistant, EMT, etc.
Some experience working in education or with a community organization.
I have some experience working in a lab setting or doing research, writing proposals, and writing about my findings.
I have some experience working with computers, databases, or information systems.

results.title: executive
results.description: You have a natural ability to lead and make decisions. You thrive in high-pressure environments and enjoy taking charge of projects and people.
results.detailedDestription: You're an organized go-getter who's interested in the business side of health care. The idea of planning, directing, and coordinating medical and health services intrigues you. Adapting to an ever-changing landscape of health care laws, regulations, and technology doesn't phase you. You may already have a background in business or health care and find yourself ready for the responsibilities of management.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Executive may like to develop plans and communicate them to a team. They enjoy helping others do their best at work.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled at leading and communicating with others. They have good attention to detail and enjoy analyzing information and using technology.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Executive's path often involve working with health care providers and managing staff or finances.

tabs.title: Courses
tabs.content: The Executive may have taken college courses in accounting, administration, ethics, or economics.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A hospital or physician's office are common workplaces for The Executive, although they may also work in a residential care facility or government agency.

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Many jobs in this field require college courses in things like accounting, administration, ethics, or economics. Some roles require a bachelor's or master's degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience in an administrative or clinical role tend to be a good fit for this The Executive's career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of medical and health services managers over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description:
For medical and health services managers, ranging from $83K to $119K averages
U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you do have a bachelor’s degree and some work experience, an MBA in Healthcare Management is a smart next step. This MBA concentration will use a health care lens to give you a broad overview of business ethics, law, leadership, accounting, marketing, budgeting, and planning.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, many universities offer a Bachelor’s in Health Administration. You can often earn these degrees online in an accelerated format.

Colleges and universities have different names for their programs, so your preferred institution might call the degree by a different name—just look for a description that includes both health care and business.

results.title: Practitioner
results.description: You enjoy working directly with people to help them solve problems and improve their lives. You have a hands-on approach and prefer to be in the field rather than behind a desk.

tabs.title: Motivation
tabs.content: The Practitioner likes to help people. They enjoy improving a person’s health or quality of life.

tabs.title: Skills
tabs.content: This role is skilled in empathetic communication and tends to be emotionally stable. They have strong problem-solving and interpersonal skills.

tabs.title: Works With
tabs.content: Careers in The Practitioner’s path work with patients and other medical professionals. They may be interested in all patients or those with a specific need.

tabs.title: Setting
tabs.content: A physician’s office, hospital, or outpatient care center are common workplaces for The Practitioner.s

tabs.title: Education
tabs.content: Jobs in this field often require college courses in physical sciences or health care. Many roles require a bachelor’s, masters, or professional degree.

tabs.title: Experience
tabs.content: People with experience working in a lab setting or with patients as a nurse, medical assistant, EMT tend to be a good fit for The Practitioner’s career path.

stats.title: Growth
stats.description: In employment of healthcare occupations over the next decade

stats.title: Median Salary
stats.description:
For healthcare practitioners and technical occupations, ranging from $30K to $163K averages
U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

stats.title: Job Openings
stats.description: Predicted annually over the next decade due to workers retiring or transferring careers

degreeTabs.title: Master's
degreeTabs.content:
If you have a bachelor’s degree and want to further specialize your studies, these are some popular master’s in the health field:

  • Master of Science in Nursing (MSN): This program expands your nursing skill set and prepares you for roles such as nurse administrator, nurse educator, clinical nurse specialist, and more
  • Master of Physician Assistant Studies: This program can prepare you to become a certified physician assistant, health educator, medical services manager, and more
  • Master of Occupational Therapy (MOT): This is often the minimum credential required to practice occupational therapy, while many go on to earn the Doctor of Occupational Therapy

degreeTabs.title: Professional
degreeTabs.content:
To reach the pinnacle of patient care, you can earn a professional doctorate such as:

  • Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP)
  • Medical Doctor (MD)
  • Doctor of Dental Surgery (DDS)
  • Doctor of Dental Medicine (DMD)
  • Doctor of Osteopathic Medicine (DO)
  • Doctor of Pharmacy (PharmD)

degreeTabs.title: Bachelor's
degreeTabs.content:
If you don’t already have a bachelor’s degree, there are many good options to pursue based on your career of interest. Some popular ones include:

  • Bachelor of Science in Nursing (BSN): This program may allow for specialization into specific areas of nursing and often qualifies students to pursue nursing licensure in their state
  • Bachelor’s in Biology: This is a popular undergraduate degree for students who will go on to pursue a master’s or professional doctorate.
  • Bachelor’s in Nutrition and Dietetics: This degree can prepare you to work in roles such as health and wellness, K-12 nutrition programming, nutrition education, food labeling, and more. If you become a Registered Dietitian Nutritionist, there are even more roles available.

results.description: You have a passion for teaching and sharing knowledge with others. You are patient, empathetic, and have a talent for explaining complex ideas in simple terms.

schools.title: University of North Texas
schools.subTitle: Health Sciences Center
schools.description: Located in Fort Worth, Texas, UNT’s Health Sciences Center is one of the nation’s premier academic medical centers. Its five schools specialize in Osteopathic Medicine, Biomedical Sciences, Public Health, Pharmacy, and Health Professions. No matter the area, HSC programs promote patient-centered education, research and compassionate health care.
schools.linkText: Learn About Health Sciences at UNT

schools.title: Fairleigh Dickinson
schools.description: With two New Jersey campuses and a wide range of online offerings, Fairleigh Dickinson offers flexible ways to earn your health sciences degree. Programs range from bachelor’s to master’s and professional doctorates, and there are a number of combined programs that streamline the process of earning both your undergrad and advanced degrees.

schools.title: San Diego State University
schools.subTitle: College of Health and Human Services
schools.description: Located in San Diego, California, SDSU offers a variety of health care certificates and bachelor’s, master’s, and doctoral/professional degrees. Programs in SDSU’s College of Health and Human Services provide students with a balanced and meaningful education, both inside and outside the classroom, to develop them into confident and compassionate professionals.
schools.linkText: Learn About Health and Human Services at SDSU

schools.title: University of Saint Francis
schools.description: Located in Fort Wayne, Indiana, the University of Saint Francis offers certificates, associate’s, bachelor’s and master’s degrees in health care. One-on-one faculty advising and a focus on real-world learning set USF’s programs apart. Plus, programs are developed with a Franciscan lens, which recognizes the dignity of each person and encourages serving others and society as a whole.
